page.title: 17ICE-CREAM MAKING, HOPTON
page.content: Thompsons started selling ice-cream three years ago as the milk from their six cows was not enough to sell by itself. On average there are three helpers. The ice-cream is made in the dairy by mixing together milk, cream, egg-yolk, sugar and powdered milk and heating to pasteurise it. Then it is put in a machine that beats and freezes it. All the ingredients are home produced and as natural as possible. They make strawberry, chocolate, vanilla, coffee and walnut and rum and raisin flavours; vanilla is the most popular. Ten gallons can be made at once in five to six hours. Ice-cream costs Â£1.85 for one litre. The product is sold to shops, hotels and restaurants locally and to fairs on a Victorian style stand. The busiest time is in the summer especially on Saturdays.
